Package phonebookApp

Class SavedPhoneBook

java.lang.Object
phonebookApp.PhoneBook
phonebookApp.SavedPhoneBook
public class SavedPhoneBook extends PhoneBook
an extension to PhoneBook which stores the phone data in a file.

SavedPhoneBook extends the basic PhoneBook class by providing save and load methods for storing and retrieving the PhoneBook data in a file.

Version:
2024-CI401-CW-PhoneBookApp
Author:

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    void
    addPhoneNumber(String name, String number)
    adds a name and phone number to the PhoneBook
    void
    delete()
    Here, the user may want to delete the phoneBook, so here is the functionality to do this - Luke.
    String
    getFileName()
    gets the filename associated with this SavedPhoneBook
    void
    load()
    loads PhoneBookData from the file We open the file and use Scanner with a modified delimiter to read the data from it (which is assumed to be in the format of the listing method) The file handling code may generate an IOException, so we wrap it in a try-catch block, which catches any exception and just prints a message (and returns, possibly with the data only partially loaded)
    void
    save()
    saves PhoneBookData into the file We use the listing method to create a file which we can later read back in using the load method The file handling code may generate an IOException, so we wrap it in a try-catch block, which catches any exception and just prints a message (and returns)

    • save

      public void save()
      saves PhoneBookData into the file We use the listing method to create a file which we can later read back in using the load method The file handling code may generate an IOException, so we wrap it in a try-catch block, which catches any exception and just prints a message (and returns)

    • delete

      public void delete()
      Here, the user may want to delete the phoneBook, so here is the functionality to do this - Luke.

    • load

      public void load()
      loads PhoneBookData from the file We open the file and use Scanner with a modified delimiter to read the data from it (which is assumed to be in the format of the listing method) The file handling code may generate an IOException, so we wrap it in a try-catch block, which catches any exception and just prints a message (and returns, possibly with the data only partially loaded)
